_readme: This file is the source of truth for the comparison table. To add a platform, copy an existing entry and fill in the fields. To add a feature, add the key to every platform entry. Valid values: 'yes', 'no', 'partial', 'planned', 'unknown'. Use 'notes' for any clarification.

features.label: Open Source
features.description: Source code is publicly available and auditable

features.label: Self-Hostable
features.description: You can run your own instance of the platform

features.label: Federated
features.description: Instances can communicate with each other across servers

features.label: End-to-End Encryption
features.description: Messages are encrypted so only sender and recipient can read them

features.label: No Ads
features.description: Platform does not serve advertisements

features.label: No Data Tracking
features.description: Platform does not track or sell user data

features.label: GDPR Compliant
features.description: Compliant with EU General Data Protection Regulation

features.label: Biometric Age Verification
features.description: Requires face scan or ID upload for age verification

features.label: Free to Use
features.description: Core features available at no cost

features.label: Web App
features.description: Accessible via a web browser without installation

features.label: Windows App
features.description: Native Windows desktop application

features.label: macOS App
features.description: Native macOS desktop application

features.label: Linux App
features.description: Native Linux desktop application

features.label: Android App
features.description: Native Android mobile application

features.label: iOS App
features.description: Native iOS mobile application

features.label: Docker Install
features.description: Can be deployed via Docker or Docker Compose

features.label: Voice Chat
features.description: Real-time voice communication in channels or rooms

features.label: Video Chat
features.description: Real-time video communication

features.label: Screen Sharing
features.description: Ability to share your screen with others

features.label: System Audio in Screen Share
features.description: Can share system/desktop audio during screen share

features.label: Text Channels
features.description: Persistent text chat channels within a server or space

features.label: File Sharing
features.description: Upload and share files within chats

features.label: GIF & Embed Support
features.description: Inline GIFs, image previews, and link embeds in chat

features.label: Threads & Forums
features.description: Threaded replies or forum-style channels

features.label: Bots & Automation
features.description: Ability to create or run automated bots in channels

features.label: Webhooks
features.description: Incoming webhooks for posting from external services

features.label: Role Management
features.description: Assign roles with specific permissions to users

features.label: Server / Space Organization
features.description: Hierarchical organization of communities, categories, and channels

features.label: Event Scheduling
features.description: Create and display scheduled events with RSVP

features.label: Raid Planner / Group Activity Tools
features.description: Structured tools for organizing group activities, signups, and role assignments

features.label: Invite Links & Guest Access
features.description: Shareable links allowing users to join without an account

features.label: Admin GUI
features.description: Graphical admin panel for managing users, rooms, and permissions

features.label: Migration Assistant
features.description: Tools to import server structure or message history from another platform

features.label: Bridges to Other Platforms
features.description: Connect to other platforms (Discord, Slack, Telegram, etc.)

features.label: Discord API Compatible
features.description: Supports Discord's API, allowing existing Discord bots to work

features.label: Docs / Wiki Channels
features.description: Dedicated channel type for creating and maintaining long-form documents or wikis within a server

features.label: List / Task Channels
features.description: Built-in channel type for to-do lists, task tracking, or workflow management

features.label: Media Gallery Channels
features.description: Dedicated channel type for image and video galleries with pop-out player

features.label: Scheduled Announcements
features.description: Ability to write and schedule posts to be published automatically at a future date and time

features.label: Tournament / Bracket Tools
features.description: Native tools for organising competitive gaming tournaments and brackets

features.label: No Premium Tier Required
features.description: All core features are fully available without a paid subscription — no equivalent of Discord Nitro required

features.label: Rich Calendar Tools
features.description: Advanced calendar system beyond basic event posting. Includes: dedicated calendar channel type, month/upcoming list views, per-event RSVP with Going/Maybe/Declined, attendance limits, repeating/recurring events, event-level permissions, separate availability/scheduling channels for collecting member availability via drag-and-drop, aggregate cross-server calendar view in user profile, automatic local timezone display, and embeddable forms within calendar events

features.label: Message TTL / Auto-Expiry
features.description: Configurable automatic deletion of messages after a set period (e.g. 1 year). Distinct from manual deletion — applies server or channel-wide on a schedule.

features.label: Persistent Voice Channels
features.description: Always-on voice channels users can freely hop in and out of at any time, independent of any specific call or message. Distinct from call-based voice (Jitsi/Zulip model) where a call must be initiated per message.

features.label: Large Community Moderation Tools
features.description: Tooling suited for communities of thousands: automod, raid/bot protection, mass ban/kick, audit logs, moderation appeal workflows, and ban/warning history per user.

features.label: Mobile Device Hosting
features.description: Server instance can be hosted directly from a phone or mobile device, allowing self-hosting without dedicated hardware or a VPS.

features.label: Per-User Audio Output Control
features.description: Each user can individually adjust the audio output volume of other members in a voice channel, including amplification above 100% (e.g. Discord supported 0–200% per user). Separate from global volume.

features.label: Community Discovery
features.description: Built-in or official directory for discovering and joining public communities. Includes in-app search, official web directories (like Disboard for Discord or matrixrooms.info for Matrix), or federated discovery mechanisms. Distinct from just invite links — this is about browsing and finding communities you don't know exist yet.

features.label: Self-Hosting License
features.description: Can you self-host without commercial license restrictions? Yes = freely self-hostable (open source), Partial = requires commercial license, No = not self-hostable

features.label: Freemium Limitations
features.description: Does the free tier have significant limitations? No = no limitations, Partial = minor limitations (storage, features), Yes = significant limitations (message history caps, user limits)

features.label: Enterprise Tier Available
features.description: Is there a separate enterprise offering with support/SLAs?

features.label: Hardware Required
features.description: Must you provide your own hardware (server/VPS) to use this platform? yes = self-hosted only, no = cloud option available

features.label: AutoMod / Content Filtering
features.description: Automated content moderation - spam detection, keyword filters, mention limits, link filtering

features.label: Audit Logs
features.description: Track all moderator actions, message edits, role changes, and administrative activities

features.label: User Timeout / Mute
features.description: Temporarily or permanently silence users without banning them

features.label: Raid Protection
features.description: Anti-raid and anti-spam measures - verification levels, join rate limits, member screening

features.label: Message Reporting
features.description: Users can report problematic messages/content for moderator review

features.label: Age Verification
features.description: Age verification system (may include invasive methods like ID upload or biometric scanning)

features.label: ID / Biometric Verification
features.description: Identity verification requiring government ID upload and/or face scanning - major privacy concern

features.label: AI Features / Training on User Data
features.description: Platform has built-in AI features (chatbots, summarization) OR trains AI models on user conversations

features.label: AI-Generated Codebase ('Vibe-Coded')
features.description: Platform codebase was primarily generated using AI tools (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, etc.) rather than traditionally developed. May indicate security/quality concerns.

platforms.name: Discord
platforms.description: The dominant chat platform for gaming and online communities. Included as the baseline for comparison.
platforms.notes: SECURITY CONCERN (Google Sheet assessment): Community rates security history as 'Bad'. Baseline platform. Implementing biometric age verification in the UK as of 2025.

feature_notes.system_audio_sharing: Windows and macOS only, not Linux
feature_notes.free_to_use: Freemium — Nitro subscription for extra features
feature_notes.raid_planner: Basic events only, no dedicated raid planning tools
feature_notes.biometric_age_verification: Required for UK users accessing age-restricted content as of 2025
feature_notes.scheduled_announcements: Scheduled messages available but limited — no native scheduled announcement channel type
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Nitro subscription required for animated avatars, higher upload limits, custom emoji across servers, and other features
feature_notes.per_user_audio_output: Each user can set 0–200% individual volume per member in voice channels — a much-requested feature missing from most alternatives
feature_notes.large_community_moderation: Comprehensive automod, audit logs, raid protection, timeout, mass prune — benchmark for large community moderation
feature_notes.message_ttl: No server-wide TTL — messages persist indefinitely unless manually deleted
feature_notes.community_discovery: In-app server discovery plus extensive third-party directories like Disboard, top.gg, and discord.me
feature_notes.freemium_limitations: Nitro unlocks higher upload limits, better streaming quality, server boosts
feature_notes.automod: Comprehensive AutoMod with keyword filters, spam detection, mention limits, custom rules
feature_notes.audit_logs: Full audit logs tracking all mod actions, message edits, role changes
feature_notes.user_timeout_mute: Timeout feature (temporary mute), plus permanent mute and kick/ban
feature_notes.raid_protection: Verification levels, member screening, DM spam filters, phone verification
feature_notes.message_reporting: Users can report messages, admins review in safety dashboard
feature_notes.age_verification: Planned: Teen accounts with restricted features. Requires government ID or face scan for age verification (UK pilot 2025)
feature_notes.id_verification: Planned: Face scanning and government ID verification for age-gating. Privacy concerns raised by community.
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: Clyde AI chatbot (discontinued 2024), conversation summaries in testing. May train on user data.

platforms.name: Element
platforms.description: Flagship Matrix client. Used by German Bundeswehr (military), French government, and International Criminal Court for secure communications. Full-featured, cross-platform, supports E2EE.
platforms.notes:
Matrix protocol's most mature client. E2EE by default using Olm (1-to-1) and Megolm (groups), inspired by Signal's Double Ratchet.

⚠️ PERMISSION INHERITANCE PROBLEM: Matrix Spaces don't inherit permissions. Must manually configure permissions for EVERY SINGLE ROOM. Adding moderator role to 50-room space = 50 manual configurations. Synapse admin tools are bare-bones. Shell scripts often needed for bulk operations.

⚠️ MODERATION REQUIRES DRAUPNIR: Cannot ban user from entire server without third-party tools. Must ban from each room individually. Draupnir bot (NLnet-funded, actively maintained) is ESSENTIAL for moderation at scale. Handles distributed ban lists, policy rooms, protection.

⚠️ DEVICE VERIFICATION UX: Each new client (phone, desktop, different app) requires device verification via emoji/QR codes. Crypto is solid (prevents MITM attacks) but UX is brutal for non-technical users.

BOT ECOSYSTEM: Maubot (Python framework) is mostly unmaintained graveyard. Draupnir is the exception - actively maintained, essential.

BRIDGING STRENGTH: Native bridges for Discord, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, IRC. Slack bridge retired by Matrix.org (must self-host). Fully supported by Matterbridge (30+ platforms).

VOICE/VIDEO: Matrix 2.0 added Element Call. Works, not Discord-quality yet. Resource intensive (4GB RAM VPS sweats on group calls).

Real-world assessment (mvh, Feb 2026): "Choose Matrix if privacy, decentralization, and federation are non-negotiable. You have technical chops to deal with permission management hell. You're willing to run Draupnir for moderation."

Used by German Bundeswehr for classified communications, French government, International Criminal Court. Serious privacy and security credentials.

feature_notes.role_management: Uses Matrix power levels rather than named roles — functional but less intuitive than Discord
feature_notes.webhooks: Possible via bridges but no native simple webhook URL
feature_notes.gif_embed_support: Basic embed support, GIF picker limited
feature_notes.invite_links_guest_access: Guest access exists in Matrix protocol but inconsistently surfaced in UI Invite workflow is complex — each user must be invited to each channel individually, not just to the space/server
feature_notes.admin_gui: Element Admin and Synapse-Admin available separately UI described as confusing and difficult for average users — security features add UX friction
feature_notes.message_ttl: Matrix protocol supports retention policies but implementation varies by homeserver and client
feature_notes.persistent_voice_channels: MatrixRTC supports persistent voice rooms but experience varies by client
feature_notes.large_community_moderation: Draupnir and Mjolnir bots provide moderation at scale but require setup
feature_notes.community_discovery: matrixrooms.info and other directories exist but discovery is fragmented and not integrated into clients
feature_notes.self_hosting_license: Synapse server is open source (Apache 2.0), freely self-hostable
feature_notes.automod: Requires Draupnir or Mjolnir moderation bot for advanced features
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No built-in AI features. Self-hosted/federated means no centralized data collection for training.

platforms.name: Cinny
platforms.description: A clean, simple Matrix client with a Discord-like aesthetic. Good for users who want Matrix without Element's complexity.
platforms.notes: Actively developed. No mobile app yet. Good entry point for Discord refugees.

feature_notes.voice_chat: Not yet implemented — text-focused client
feature_notes.threads_forums: Basic thread support, no forum channels
feature_notes.mobile_app: No native app — web app is mobile-accessible but not optimised
feature_notes.community_discovery: matrixrooms.info and other directories exist but discovery is fragmented and not integrated into clients

platforms.name: Commet
platforms.description: Feature-rich Matrix client focused on casual communities. Closest to Discord in terms of features.
platforms.notes: CRITICAL SECURITY VULNERABILITY (Feb 17, 2026): Cryptographic issues discovered in Matrix's Rust library (vodozemac). See https://soatok.blog/2026/02/17/cryptographic-issues-in-matrixs-rust-library-vodozemac/ SECURITY CONCERN (Google Sheet assessment): Community rates security history as 'Bad'. Written in Flutter. Supports GIF search (proxied for privacy), events, stickers, voice channels via MatrixRTC.

feature_notes.gif_embed_support: GIF search proxied through Commet's servers to reduce tracking
feature_notes.raid_planner: Event scheduling exists — dedicated raid planning tools not yet available
feature_notes.voice_chat: Uses MatrixRTC + LiveKit, scales well
feature_notes.community_discovery: matrixrooms.info and other directories exist but discovery is fragmented and not integrated into clients
feature_notes.automod: Requires Draupnir or Mjolnir moderation bot for advanced features
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No built-in AI features. Federated Matrix client.

platforms.name: FluffyChat
platforms.description: Beginner-friendly Matrix client with a focus on mobile and simplicity.
platforms.notes: CRITICAL SECURITY VULNERABILITY (Feb 17, 2026): Cryptographic issues discovered in Matrix's Rust library (vodozemac). See https://soatok.blog/2026/02/17/cryptographic-issues-in-matrixs-rust-library-vodozemac/ SECURITY CONCERN (Google Sheet assessment): Community rates security history as 'Bad'. Best for non-technical users and mobile-first users. Less feature-rich than Element or Commet.

feature_notes.voice_chat: 1:1 calls supported, large voice channels limited
feature_notes.community_discovery: matrixrooms.info and other directories exist but discovery is fragmented and not integrated into clients

platforms.name: SchildiChat
platforms.description: A Matrix client based on Element with a more Discord-like feel and additional quality-of-life features.
platforms.notes: Built on Element codebase with extra features and UI tweaks. Good for users who want Element's stability with a friendlier interface.

feature_notes.community_discovery: matrixrooms.info and other directories exist but discovery is fragmented and not integrated into clients
feature_notes.automod: Requires Draupnir or Mjolnir moderation bot for advanced features
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No built-in AI features. Federated Matrix client.

platforms.name: Stoat (formerly Revolt)
platforms.description: Open-source, privacy-respecting Discord alternative. Most Discord-like experience outside of Matrix. EU-based.
platforms.notes:
⚠️ ALPHA QUALITY (Feb 2026): Voice channels currently NON-FUNCTIONAL due to major infrastructure migration. Mobile apps in trial phase. Bot ecosystem immature with many abandoned projects. E2EE status unclear - mentioned as future goal but no implementation timeline. Breaks regularly. NOT production-ready.

NO FEDERATION: Each Stoat server is isolated - separate accounts needed per server (like Zulip). No portable identity across instances. Different from Matrix's federated model.

MINIMAL BRIDGING: Community bridges exist for Discord (revcord) and Telegram only. NOT supported by Matterbridge. No IRC, Matrix, or Slack bridges.

Real-world assessment (mvh, Feb 2026): "Choose Stoat if you want Discord's UX exactly and are willing to wait for it to mature. Skip if you need production-ready software now, voice chat matters, or bridging is important." Recommendation: Wait until more mature.

Originally named Revolt, rebranded after cease-and-desist. Open source (AGPL-3.0), self-hostable, Discord-like UI with near-zero learning curve. Has genuine potential but needs time to mature.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: E2EE for DMs is planned but not yet released
feature_notes.federated: Each Stoat server is isolated. Separate accounts needed per server. No portable identity.
feature_notes.screen_sharing: Screen sharing has never been supported
feature_notes.voice_chat: Voice channels currently non-functional due to infrastructure migration (Feb 2026)
feature_notes.video_chat: Video chat has never been supported
feature_notes.mobile_app: Beta Android and iOS apps available — iOS app especially rough, Android feels better. Sign-up verification slow (10+ hours reported) during user influx
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Previously used AI-generated commits but removed them after community backlash. Developer explicitly states Stoat's foundation predates vibe-coding (public beta 2021, ChatGPT late 2022). Currently maintains strong anti-AI stance.
feature_notes.self_hostable: Available but not prominently documented. See: https://github.com/stoatchat/self-hosted
feature_notes.bridges: Community bridges for Discord and Telegram only. NOT supported by Matterbridge.

platforms.name: Valour
platforms.description: Open-source, volunteer-built platform with unique multi-window chat. Built with Blazor/WebAssembly.
platforms.notes: Unique multi-window feature allows chatting across multiple channels simultaneously. Voice chat pending funding.

feature_notes.desktop_app: PWA only — no native desktop app
feature_notes.mobile_app: PWA only — no native mobile app
feature_notes.voice_chat: Planned but requires funding to implement
feature_notes.docker_install: Partial — setup more complex than other platforms
feature_notes.self_hostable: Planned 'coming soon' but not available as of Feb 2026

platforms.name: Nerimity
platforms.description: Open-source Discord alternative with a clean interface. Primarily centralized hosting model.
platforms.notes: Open source client and backend. Smaller community than Stoat. NSFW content fully banned.

feature_notes.mobile_app: Android app available, no iOS app

platforms.name: Sharkord
platforms.description: Self-hosted chat platform designed for privacy-conscious communities.
platforms.notes: Has a demo available at demo.sharkord.com. No mobile apps yet.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: TLS transport encryption only — not end-to-end
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Minimal documentation, rapid development timeline. Status unclear.

platforms.name: Spacebar
platforms.description: Open-source, self-hosted platform compatible with the Discord API — existing Discord bots and clients can connect.
platforms.notes: The only platform that supports Discord's API, meaning existing Discord bots work without modification.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: TLS transport encryption only
feature_notes.voice_chat: No voice channel support at time of writing despite Discord API compatibility
feature_notes.discord_api_compatible: Key differentiator — existing Discord bots work without modification
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Explicitly bans AI code: 'AI code due to not being GPLv3 compatible is not allowed in this repo'

platforms.name: Fluxer
platforms.description: Open-source self-hosted chat platform (AGPL licensed).
platforms.notes: AGPLv3 with CLA. Launched public beta early 2025. Sold ~1,000 Visionary lifetime plans ($299 each) before Discord age verification announcement drove massive traction. Single developer (Hampus Kraft), now crowdfunded/bootstrapped with ~$300k from Visionary sales. Native mobile app in development with Flutter developers. No VC funding.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Roadmap 2026: Opt-in 'secret chats' (ephemeral, E2EE sessions). No plans for full-platform E2EE. LiveKit supports E2EE for calls but not yet implemented.
feature_notes.self_hostable: Self-hosting not recommended at this time — documentation and support coming soon
feature_notes.mobile_app: PWA currently. Native Flutter app in development with community developers (post Discord age verification surge)
feature_notes.open_source: AGPLv3 + CLA. CLA allows commercial licensing for companies wanting to run internally without copyleft. Committed to no paywalled features or forced upgrades.
feature_notes.threads_forums: Roadmap 2026: Slack/Reddit-style threads with hierarchical/linear views, upvoting/downvoting, private forum threads
feature_notes.federated: Roadmap 2026: Distributed E2EE federation relays, OAuth2 auth via home instance
feature_notes.community_discovery: Roadmap 2026: In-app and public (no login) community discovery for published forums
feature_notes.bots_automation: Roadmap 2026: Slash commands, modals, components, interactions — Discord feature parity planned
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Developer uses LLMs as a 'rubber duck' debugging tool but writes all code personally. See: https://blog.fluxer.app/how-i-built-fluxer-a-discord-like-chat-app/

platforms.name: Loqa
platforms.description: Open-source, self-hosted platform with E2EE DMs and zero telemetry.
platforms.notes: Strong privacy focus — zero telemetry claim. E2EE for direct messages.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: E2EE for DMs only, not group channels

platforms.name: DCTS
platforms.description: Community-driven, self-hosted chat platform.
platforms.notes: Desktop app available. Plugins supported.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: TLS transport encryption only

platforms.name: Root
platforms.description: VC-funded commercial chat platform with built-in app ecosystem. Polished but closed source.
platforms.notes: ⚠️ SUSPICIOUS PLATFORM - AVOID: No revenue model (no ads/premium/donations), NFT-VC backed, advertised features don't exist, anti-NSFW. Community: 'Stay away from Root.' Backed by $9M seed funding. Strong features but commercial trajectory carries same long-term risks as Discord.

feature_notes.no_ads: No ads currently but VC-funded — monetization model may change
feature_notes.no_data_tracking: Shares data with third parties per privacy policy
feature_notes.migration_assistant: Has 'Discord Themes' feature that imports/converts Discord servers
feature_notes.video_chat: Video bitrate is low quality — streams appear blurry according to user reports
feature_notes.screen_sharing: Video quality in screenshare is poor — blurry at standard bitrate
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Google Sheet community assessment: NOT vibe-safe. May contain AI-generated code.

platforms.name: Guilded (discontinued)
platforms.description: Feature-rich gaming community platform acquired by Roblox in 2021 for $90M. Shut down December 19, 2025. Had best-in-class raid planning, rich calendar tools, docs/wiki channels, and task lists — the closest Discord feature-parity alternative that existed.
platforms.notes: Shut down December 19, 2025. Roblox required all users to link a Roblox account from July 2024, driving away non-gaming communities. Included for historical reference as it represented the most feature-complete Discord alternative ever built.

feature_notes.raid_planner: Best-in-class raid and event tools — a key differentiator
feature_notes.rich_calendar_tools: Full calendar system: dedicated calendar channel type, month and upcoming list views, per-event RSVP (Going/Maybe/Declined), attendance limits, repeating events, event-level permissions, separate scheduling channels for collecting availability via drag-and-drop, aggregate cross-server calendar in user profile, automatic local timezone display, and embeddable forms within events
feature_notes.tournament_brackets: Native bracket and tournament organisation tools — a key differentiator for competitive gaming communities
feature_notes.per_user_audio_output: Per-user volume supported but range more limited than Discord's 0–200%
feature_notes.community_discovery: Had native server discovery and browse features before shutdown

platforms.name: Telegram
platforms.description: Large-scale messaging platform with up to 200,000 members per group. Open source clients, closed backend.
platforms.notes: Requires phone number. E2EE only in Secret Chats — regular chats are not E2EE.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Secret Chats only — standard group chats and channels are NOT end-to-end encrypted
feature_notes.open_source: Client apps are open source, server backend is closed
feature_notes.no_ads: Ads shown in public channels on free tier
feature_notes.media_gallery_channels: Channels can be used as media galleries but no dedicated gallery channel type
feature_notes.scheduled_announcements: Messages and posts can be scheduled natively
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Telegram Premium subscription required for some features like larger uploads and exclusive stickers
feature_notes.message_ttl: Auto-delete timers available per chat (1 day, 1 week, 1 month)
feature_notes.community_discovery: Search for public channels and groups built into the app
feature_notes.video_chat: Group video chat bitrate described as poor quality
feature_notes.system_audio_sharing: System audio sharing in group chats has echo cancellation issues — users can hear themselves, audio cuts in and out
feature_notes.freemium_limitations: Premium adds faster downloads, larger uploads (4GB), exclusive stickers, ads removal
feature_notes.raid_protection: Anti-spam features, aggressive join requirements for large groups
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: Supports AI bots via bot ecosystem, no native AI features

platforms.name: TeamSpeak
platforms.description: Long-running voice-focused platform. Predates Discord. Not recommended for casual community use due to dated UX.
platforms.notes: Still used by some gaming communities. Voice quality is excellent but UI is outdated.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Voice is AES-encrypted between client and server but server can decrypt — not true E2EE
feature_notes.text_channels: Text chat is functional but minimal — not a primary feature
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Free for small servers, licensing required for larger deployments
feature_notes.screen_sharing: P2P streaming only supports one-to-one, not one-to-many from voice channel. Group chat streaming works — can stream to group chat while talking in server simultaneously. Allows custom bitrate settings and 60fps streaming. Supports streaming multiple windows simultaneously. Connection can be slow/buggy (10+ minute waits, duplicate users reported).
feature_notes.self_hosting_license: Free server for non-commercial use (32 slots), commercial license required for larger deployments
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No AI features, voice-focused legacy platform

platforms.name: Mumble
platforms.description: Open-source, self-hosted voice chat with true end-to-end encryption. Minimal text features.
platforms.notes: Excellent audio quality and true E2EE for voice. Very low overhead. Not beginner friendly.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: True E2EE for voice — one of the few platforms with this
feature_notes.message_ttl: Text chat history not persisted long-term by default
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No AI features, voice-focused legacy platform

platforms.name: Signal
platforms.description: Gold standard for private messaging. Best-in-class encryption. Limited community/server features.
platforms.notes: Requires phone number. Excellent for small groups but lacks Discord-style community features.

feature_notes.text_channels: Group chats exist but no server/channel hierarchy
feature_notes.web_app: Desktop-linked web interface only, no standalone web app
feature_notes.message_ttl: Disappearing messages supported with configurable TTL per conversation
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: Explicitly privacy-focused, no AI features, no data collection for training

platforms.name: Zulip
platforms.description: Fully open-source team chat with a unique topic-based threading model. Strongest text chat experience of any self-hosted option. Voice/video via Jitsi integration.
platforms.notes:
⚠️ NO FEDERATION - MULTI-COMMUNITY DEALBREAKER: Every Zulip server is an island. 3 communities = 3 separate accounts. No single sign-on, no portable identity. Username@company.zulipchat.com completely separate from username@mydomain.com. Deliberate architectural choice prioritizing organizational control. 20 communities = 20 accounts/logins = NOT SUSTAINABLE.

E2EE REALITY: E2EE ONLY for push notification content. Actual messages stored as PLAINTEXT in PostgreSQL by design. Team chose features over encryption. E2EE breaks: search, shared history, server-side features. If you need message-level E2EE, Zulip is not your platform.

THREADING MODEL: EVERY message must belong to a topic within a channel. Always. No exceptions. Can't just post "hey what's up" - must choose/create a topic. Solves large organization chat chaos (50 people, 8 conversations in one channel). Biggest barrier to adoption from Discord - feels weird at first.

VOICE/VIDEO: No native persistent voice channels like Discord. Integration-based: click button, generates Jitsi/Zoom/BigBlueButton meeting link. Different paradigm entirely - not drop-in/hang-out voice.

BOT ECOSYSTEM: 120+ native integrations (GitHub, Jira, Sentry, PagerDuty, etc.). Slack-compatible webhooks. Python bot framework is "excellent" - clean APIs, good documentation. Zapier and IFTTT support.

BRIDGING: Native bridges for IRC (great), Matrix (bidirectional), Slack (bidirectional). Fully supported by Matterbridge. Legitimately good, not Matrix-level extensive but solid.

SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: 2GB RAM (small), 4GB (production). PostgreSQL, Redis, RabbitMQ required. Very good Docker support.

Real-world assessment (mvh, Feb 2026): "Choose Zulip if you're running a technical organization where organized conversation matters more than casual chat. Skip if you need federation, message-level E2EE is required, or you're part of many communities (don't want 20 separate accounts)."

Threading model makes sense once you use it - conversations stay organized, notification management sane. But lack of portable identity across servers is dealbreaker at scale.

feature_notes.voice_chat: Via Jitsi integration only — not native. Uses call-per-message model, not persistent always-on channels
feature_notes.persistent_voice_channels: Jitsi calls are initiated per message — users cannot freely hop in and out of an always-on channel like Discord
feature_notes.threads_forums: Unique topic-based model: every message belongs to a topic within a channel. Takes adjustment for Discord users but very powerful for productivity communities
feature_notes.large_community_moderation: Good moderation tools for productivity communities, less suited for large open social communities
feature_notes.message_ttl: Configurable message retention policies per stream
feature_notes.migration_assistant: Some import tools available for Slack and HipChat, limited Discord support
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No built-in AI features. Self-hosted option means user controls data.
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Strict AI policy: permits AI assistance but STRICTLY disallows AI commits with zero oversight. See: https://github.com/zulip/zulip/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: E2EE ONLY for push notification content. Messages stored as plaintext in PostgreSQL.

platforms.name: Rocket.Chat
platforms.description: Mature, feature-rich open-source team chat. Strong self-hosting story and enterprise feature set. Free tier capped at 50 users — significant limitation for large communities.
platforms.notes: One of the most mature self-hosted options. Voice calls are enterprise-only on the free tier. Free instance hard-capped at 50 users — must contact support to raise this limit, making it impractical for large open communities.

feature_notes.free_to_use: Free tier hard-capped at 50 users — must contact support to raise limit. Enterprise license required for larger deployments
feature_notes.voice_chat: Voice calls are enterprise-only on free tier
feature_notes.video_chat: Video calls are enterprise-only on free tier
feature_notes.screen_sharing: Screen sharing enterprise-only on free tier
feature_notes.persistent_voice_channels: No persistent always-on voice channels — calls are initiated per conversation
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Enterprise license required for voice/video and >50 users
feature_notes.federated: Matrix federation bridge available but not native
feature_notes.freemium_limitations: Cloud has message history limits, self-hosted is unlimited
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: AI chatbot integrations available via marketplace
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Google Sheet community assessment: NOT vibe-safe. May contain AI-generated code.

platforms.name: Roger Wilco
platforms.description: Pioneer VoIP application for gaming (1999-2003). First major voice chat tool designed for multiplayer games. Used peer-to-peer connection model.
platforms.notes: Developed by Resounding Technology, later acquired by GameSpy. Final version released July 8, 2003. Used push-to-talk. Pioneered gaming voice chat but was supplanted by TeamSpeak and Ventrilo.

feature_notes.self_hostable: Base Station server could be hosted on Linux/FreeBSD/Windows but was proprietary
feature_notes.server_organization: Channel-based system with public/private channel browser
feature_notes.community_discovery: Built-in channel browser displayed all public channels

platforms.name: Xfire
platforms.description: Gaming-focused instant messaging and social platform (2003-2015). Combined voice chat, game tracking, screenshots, and video recording. Shutdown June 2015.
platforms.notes: Acquired by Viacom/MTV Networks in 2006 for $110M. Had 24M+ registered users. Discontinued June 12, 2015. Xf1re is an unofficial open-source reimplementation.

feature_notes.community_discovery: Game server browser and clan/community discovery built in
feature_notes.screen_sharing: Game screenshot capture and video recording, not live screen sharing

platforms.name: Skype
platforms.description: Microsoft's video calling and instant messaging platform (2003-present). Once dominant for voice/video calls, now largely superseded by Discord, Zoom, and Teams. Still maintained but feature development minimal.
platforms.notes: Launched 2003, acquired by Microsoft 2011. Was the default video calling app for a decade. Now largely replaced by Teams for business use and Discord for gaming/communities. Still active but receives minimal feature updates. Requires Microsoft account.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Private conversations support E2EE, but group chats do not
feature_notes.no_ads: Some promotional content present in free tier
feature_notes.system_audio_sharing: System audio sharing available on Windows and macOS only
feature_notes.text_channels: Group chats exist but no server/channel hierarchy — designed for 1:1 and small group calls, not communities
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Skype Credit and subscription plans exist for calling phone numbers, but core chat/video features are free
feature_notes.bots_automation: Limited bot support — primarily designed for human-to-human communication
feature_notes.per_user_audio_output: Individual volume control per participant supported

platforms.name: GameVox
platforms.description: Voice chat platform for gaming communities launched in 2025. Features 3D spatial audio, proximity voice for FiveM/alt:V/RedM roleplay servers. Free tier limited to 50 members.
platforms.notes: Launched 2025 in open beta. No email/phone required. Uses Opus HD codec. Paid tiers unlock features (per-server not per-user). AWS-hosted with multi-region voice servers.

feature_notes.free_to_use: Free tier: 50 members max, 3 voice channels, 8 text channels, 2GB storage
feature_notes.voice_chat: 3D spatial/proximity audio for roleplay servers. Adjustable voice ranges (whisper 3m to megaphone 100m)

platforms.name: Kloak
platforms.description: SECURITY BREACH (Feb 20, 2026): Platform compromised. Attacker gained access to full user list and private messages. Privacy-first Discord alternative with key-based authentication (no email/password). If key is lost, account cannot be recovered.
platforms.notes: CRITICAL SECURITY INCIDENT (Feb 20, 2026): Users report receiving unsolicited messages from 'awdwadwa' claiming platform compromise. Attacker demonstrated ability to: (1) Access full user list, (2) Send mass private messages to users not in friends list, (3) Read private messages. Shortly after, account creation disabled for hours. DO NOT USE until security audit completed. Previous info: Launched early 2025. Uses cryptographic keys instead of email/password. Lost key = lost account (intentional design for privacy). AI-generated codebase status unclear.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: E2EE for DMs planned but not yet implemented
feature_notes.desktop_app: Web app can be installed as PWA — no native desktop app yet
feature_notes.open_source: Closed source but built with privacy-first principles. Minimal data storage by design.
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Security breach pattern (Feb 2026) similar to Paracord suggests possible vibe-coded origin with inadequate security review. Platform lacks authentication on critical endpoints.

platforms.name: Mezon
platforms.description: Open-source Discord-like platform. Self-hostable with Docker. Less mature than Rocket.Chat/Zulip.
platforms.notes: New open-source Discord alternative. Limited documentation and community. Worth watching but not mature yet.

platforms.name: SimpleX Chat
platforms.description: Open-source decentralized messaging with no user identifiers (no phone, email, or usernames). Not for large communities — designed for secure private messaging.
platforms.notes: Privacy-first design with no user identifiers. Not suitable for Discord-like communities. Server infrastructure can be self-hosted.

feature_notes.federated: Decentralized but not federated — no user identifiers, P2P via relay servers
feature_notes.invite_links_guest_access: One-time connection links — no persistent usernames
feature_notes.text_channels: Only DMs and group chats — no server/channel structure
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No AI features, no user profiling, no data collection

platforms.name: Pumble
platforms.description: Team communication tool designed as Slack alternative for businesses. Not designed for gaming/casual communities.
platforms.notes: Business productivity tool, not a Discord alternative. Included for completeness as it appears in alternative lists.

feature_notes.free_to_use: Free tier available but limited features — paid plans for businesses

platforms.name: Chanty
platforms.description: Team collaboration platform combining chat with task management. Slack alternative for small teams.
platforms.notes: Business productivity tool. Windows download only available via Microsoft Store. Not designed for gaming/casual communities.

feature_notes.desktop_app: Windows app only available via Microsoft Store
feature_notes.list_task_channels: Integrated task management — combines chat with project tracking

platforms.name: Nextcloud Talk
platforms.description: Audio/video/chat app integrated into Nextcloud self-hosted cloud platform. Part of larger file sync/collaboration suite. Not standalone Discord alternative — requires full Nextcloud.
platforms.notes: Part of Nextcloud ecosystem, not a standalone chat platform. Designed for businesses/teams using Nextcloud for file storage. HD video, E2EE calls, federation support, SIP gateway for phone dial-in. Reliable for ~5 participants without High Performance Backend (HPB) add-on.

feature_notes.federated: Federation across Nextcloud instances for group chats and calls
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: E2EE for calls. Messages not E2EE by default.
feature_notes.video_chat: Peer-to-peer reliable for ~5 participants. High Performance Backend (paid add-on) scales to thousands.
feature_notes.text_channels: Conversations, not traditional channels. Threaded messages supported.
feature_notes.event_scheduling: Deep integration with Nextcloud Calendar — event conversations created from calendar
feature_notes.bridges: Matterbridge integration allows syncing with other chat platforms
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Core features free. High Performance Backend requires Nextcloud subscription for large calls.

platforms.name: Snikket
platforms.description: Pre-configured XMPP server package. Easier to deploy than raw XMPP/Prosody. Designed for non-technical users to self-host messaging.
platforms.notes: Essentially a packaged, user-friendly XMPP server. Same underlying protocol as XMPP but with easier setup. Shows why multiple XMPP-based projects exist separately — different packaging/UX approaches to same protocol.

feature_notes.text_channels: Group chats exist but no Discord-style server/channel hierarchy
feature_notes.mobile_app: Custom Snikket app for Android/iOS built on Conversations/Siskin clients

platforms.name: Quiet
platforms.description: P2P encrypted team chat. Uses Tor for anonymity. No central server. Designed for journalists/activists, not casual communities.
platforms.notes: Extreme privacy focus using Tor. No phone numbers, no central servers. Not suitable for Discord-style communities. Shows redundancy in open source — similar goals to SimpleX but different technical approach.

feature_notes.self_hostable: P2P architecture — no servers to host. All communication via Tor network.
feature_notes.federated: P2P architecture, not federated in traditional sense

platforms.name: Roomy
platforms.description: Open-source Discord alternative. Very limited public information available. Development status unclear.
platforms.notes: Mentioned in Reddit threads but minimal documentation/community. May be inactive or very early stage. Shows ecosystem fragmentation — multiple small open-source Discord clones exist.

platforms.name: Campfire
platforms.description: Group chat by Basecamp (formerly 37signals). Retired in favor of Basecamp's built-in chat. Listed as open source in some sources but was actually proprietary.
platforms.notes: Retired by Basecamp. Functionality folded into Basecamp product. Not actually open source despite being on some lists. Shows confusion in alternative lists.

platforms.name: Colanode
platforms.description: Self-hosted collaboration platform. Minimal public information. Development status unclear.
platforms.notes: Very limited documentation. Shows ecosystem fragmentation — many small self-hosted projects with minimal traction.

platforms.name: Raven
platforms.description: Self-hosted messaging platform. Minimal public information available.
platforms.notes: Very limited information. Shows fragmentation in self-hosted messaging space.

platforms.name: Pulse Chat
platforms.description: Self-hosted communication platform with voice, video, and text chat. No government ID required. Minimal public information available.
platforms.notes: Tagline: 'Your chat app shouldn't need a background check.' Very minimal documentation. Self-hosted voice, video, and text chat. Website went live recently. Limited details on features or maturity.

feature_notes.biometric_age_verification: 'No government ID required' is a key selling point

platforms.name: Blite Chat
platforms.description: Open-source E2EE messaging with Discord-style servers, channels, voice/video. Server operator cannot read messages. Self-hostable with minimal requirements (512MB RAM for text, more for voice/video).
platforms.notes: MIT licensed. Launched early 2025. Built heavily with AI assistance (Claude). X3DH key agreement + symmetric ratchet for DMs, Sender Keys (Signal protocol) for group channels, AES-128-GCM encrypted voice/video via mediasoup SFU. SQLite, no external dependencies. Lite mode (text only, 512MB RAM) or full mode (voice/video, UDP 40000-40100). Single large initial commit (developed privately, cleaned for open source). Desktop app triggers Windows SmartScreen (no code signing cert yet). Web app at blite.chat recommended.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: X3DH key agreement + symmetric ratchet for DMs. Sender Keys (Signal protocol) for group channels. AES-128-GCM for voice/video via mediasoup SFU. Server sees only ciphertext.
feature_notes.self_hostable: Lite mode: text only, 512MB RAM. Full mode: voice/video, requires UDP 40000-40100 open. SQLite, no external dependencies. Works with nginx/Traefik/Caddy or included Caddy for auto-HTTPS.
feature_notes.desktop_app: Triggers Windows SmartScreen warning (no code signing certificate). Web app recommended for easiest/safest start.
feature_notes.open_source: MIT licensed. Single large initial commit (developed privately, cleaned for open source release). Built heavily with AI assistance (Claude).
feature_notes.federated: Self-hosted but not federated. Each instance is isolated.
feature_notes.voice_chat: E2EE voice via mediasoup SFU with AES-128-GCM encryption
feature_notes.video_chat: E2EE video via mediasoup SFU with AES-128-GCM encryption
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Explicitly states 'Built heavily with AI assistance (Claude)' in documentation. Single large initial commit suggests AI-generated codebase cleaned for release.

platforms.name: Databag
platforms.description: Tiny self-hosted federated messenger. Topic-based threads (not contact-based). Can run on Raspberry Pi Zero. Public-private key identity.
platforms.notes: Lightweight (runs on RPi Zero v1.3). Federation means nodes can communicate. E2EE optional (sealed topics). Default unsealed for server-side features. Topic-based organization instead of contact lists. Unlimited accounts per node. Audio/video requires STUN/TURN relay. Available on F-Droid, Google Play, Apple App Store.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Optional 'sealed topics' provide E2EE. Default unsealed to allow server-side features (streaming, processing). Admin cannot view sealed topics.
feature_notes.federated: Accounts on different Databag nodes can communicate. Federation protocol is Databag-specific, not Matrix/XMPP.
feature_notes.threads_forums: Topic-based threading - messages organized by topic, not contacts
feature_notes.voice_chat: Audio calls supported. Requires STUN/TURN relay server for NAT traversal.
feature_notes.video_chat: Video calls supported. Requires STUN/TURN relay server for NAT traversal.

platforms.name: Steam Chat
platforms.description: Built-in chat for Steam gaming platform. Voice, video, text, screen sharing. Massive userbase among PC gamers.
platforms.notes: Part of Steam platform (350M+ users). De facto communication for PC gaming. Group chats, voice channels, video calls. Persistent channel order. Not self-hostable or privacy-focused. Designed for gaming communities.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Variable - some encryption but not E2EE for all features
feature_notes.community_discovery: Built into Steam platform - can discover game communities, groups

platforms.name: Oldcord
platforms.description: Open-source reimplementation of 2015-2018 Discord backend. Nostalgia project preserving classic Discord experience without telemetry/bloat.
platforms.notes: GPL-3.0. Recreates Discord 2015-2018 era. Text channels, attribute search (has:tag, before:date), pinned posts, custom emotes, bot hooks. Voice via WebRTC P2P (exposes IP), standard WebRTC, or UDP. Video not yet supported. Client patcher included. No 2019+ support planned (too much commercial bloat). Desktop clients available.

feature_notes.voice_chat: Work in progress. WebRTC P2P (exposes IP, VPN recommended), standard WebRTC (browser), UDP (desktop). Minor bugs being fixed.
feature_notes.video_chat: Not yet supported. Focus on voice first.
feature_notes.discord_api_compatible: 2015-2018 Discord API compatibility. Client patcher for custom patches.
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Developer explicitly: 'we don't use AI to generate any of our code. we don't accept AI generated contributions'

platforms.name: Jami
platforms.description: GNU P2P distributed communication. Fully peer-to-peer (no central servers). Works on LAN even without internet. Formerly GNU Ring/SFLphone.
platforms.notes: GNU project backed by Free Software Foundation. True P2P - calls go directly between users. E2EE with perfect forward secrecy (X.509). DHT for node discovery. Optional username blockchain (private Ethereum). JAMS (Jami Account Management Server) for organizations. Can function as SIP client. Works on local networks without internet. Originally SFLphone (2004) → Ring (2015) → Jami (2019). Mobile app reviews report connectivity/notification issues.

feature_notes.self_hostable: P2P architecture - no traditional servers. Can self-host DHT proxy and name server. JAMS for organizations.
feature_notes.federated: P2P distributed, not federated in traditional sense. Each device is a node.
feature_notes.text_channels: 1-on-1 and group chats only. No server/channel hierarchy.
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Perfect forward secrecy with X.509 standard. All P2P communications encrypted.

platforms.name: Gajim
platforms.description: Full-featured XMPP desktop client. Python/GTK. OMEMO E2EE. Linux/Windows. No voice/video.
platforms.notes: Major XMPP desktop client (since 2004). Python/GTK3. OMEMO E2EE support. Plugin system. Desktop only (no mobile). Designed for power users. Text-focused - no native voice/video (requires Jitsi plugin). Shows XMPP ecosystem diversity.

feature_notes.self_hostable: XMPP client - requires XMPP server (Prosody, ejabberd, etc)
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: OMEMO support for E2EE messaging
feature_notes.voice_chat: Via Jitsi plugin - not native

platforms.name: Echoed
platforms.description: Privacy-focused messaging (details limited). 40 features documented in community sheet.
platforms.notes: Limited public information. Not yet open source. Desktop + web. No mobile yet. Google Sheet shows strong feature coverage (40/42). Needs more research.

feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Backend coded from scratch. Frontend has 'bits and pieces' of AI assistance but not vibe-coded.

platforms.name: Virola
platforms.description: Corporate self-hosted messenger with task management, Kanban boards, and screen sharing. Designed for businesses, not casual communities.
platforms.notes: Developed by Provide Support LLC (started 2019, released 2023-2024). Business/enterprise focus. Features: task board (Scrum/Kanban), issue tracking, unlimited file storage, LaTeX support, screen sharing with remote control, meetings scheduling, live avatars, role-based permissions. Currently free (insider preview program). Cloud demo available. NOT open source. Windows, macOS, Linux, iOS, Android clients.

feature_notes.list_task_channels: Integrated Kanban board and issue tracking - can create tasks from messages
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Self-hosted with data on your servers, but not E2EE
feature_notes.self_hosting_license: Currently free (insider preview), closed source, future licensing TBD
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Google Sheet community assessment: NOT vibe-safe. May contain AI-generated code.

platforms.name: Osmium
platforms.description: Globally distributed messaging and VoIP platform. Formerly 'Tangle'. Early access opened Feb 2026 after 2+ years development. Independent team (EU/BR).
platforms.notes: Opened early access Feb 10, 2026. Previously called 'Tangle'. Built by independent team (European/Brazilian). 'Far from perfect yet' per their own announcement. Positions as Discord alternative. Fast global messaging, voice, and video. No email required for signup (30 seconds). Very new - limited public info. Web, Windows, macOS, Linux clients available.

feature_notes.free_to_use: No email required - sign up in 30 seconds
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Google Sheet community assessment: NOT vibe-safe. May contain AI-generated code.

platforms.name: Swift IM
platforms.description: Cross-platform XMPP desktop client. Security-focused for Military/Finance/Government. Multi-user chat, security labels, keyword highlighting.
platforms.notes: Developed by Isode. Desktop only (Windows, macOS, Linux). Features: security labelling (XEP-0258), Trellis Mode (view multiple rooms simultaneously), keyword/phrase highlighting, message delivery receipts. C++/Qt based (Swiften library). Designed for security-conscious environments. Open source desktop version (Swift 4.0) with paid support packages available. NOT for mobile.

feature_notes.self_hostable: XMPP client - requires XMPP server (Prosody, ejabberd, M-Link, etc)
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: OMEMO and other XMPP E2EE extensions supported
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Open source version free, paid support packages available

platforms.name: Movim
platforms.description: Distributed social network built on XMPP. Web-based. Communities, blogging, file sharing. Compatible with Conversations/Dino clients.
platforms.notes: Web-based XMPP client + social platform. Federated via XMPP. Create Communities around topics. Compatible with ejabberd, Prosody servers. Can connect to multiple XMPP servers simultaneously. Self-hostable. Podman/Docker deployment available. More than just chat - includes blogging, events, forums, tasks. Interoperates with Conversations (Android), Dino (Desktop), other XMPP clients.

feature_notes.self_hostable: Web app that connects to XMPP servers - can self-host both Movim and server
feature_notes.federated: XMPP federation - communicates across XMPP network
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: OMEMO support via XMPP
feature_notes.text_channels: Communities and chat rooms via XMPP MUC
feature_notes.threads_forums: Communities for topic-based discussions, blogging features
feature_notes.voice_chat: Text-focused platform, no native voice/video

platforms.name: RaidCall
platforms.description: Free cloud-based voice chat for gaming (2011-2019). Supported up to 10,000 users per group. Had overlay, music streaming, low latency. Discontinued March 31, 2019.
platforms.notes: Shut down March 31, 2019. Used Speex audio engine. UDP-based for low latency. Had Flash-based in-game overlay. Free hosted servers (no rental fees). Open source reimplementation 'RiceCall' exists.

feature_notes.self_hostable: Free cloud-hosted servers provided by RaidCall — no self-hosting option
feature_notes.video_chat: Group video chat supported up to 4 people
feature_notes.community_discovery: Public group browser to discover and join groups
feature_notes.per_user_audio_output: Individual volume control per user supported
feature_notes.role_management: Channel permissions and user roles for guild/team management

platforms.name: Dolby Axon
platforms.description: Gaming voice chat platform by Dolby Laboratories (2008-2015). Featured Dolby audio technology, positional audio, and low latency. Discontinued 2015.
platforms.notes: Developed by Dolby Laboratories. Featured high-quality Dolby audio codec and 3D positional audio. Free tier available. Discontinued around 2015.

feature_notes.free_to_use: Free tier available, paid tier for advanced features
feature_notes.voice_chat: Featured Dolby audio codec and 3D positional audio — key differentiator

platforms.name: Razer Comms
platforms.description: Gaming VoIP platform by Razer Inc (2013-2016). Integrated with Razer Cortex. Featured overlay, game detection, and LFG features. Discontinued 2016.
platforms.notes: Developed by Razer Inc. Integrated with Razer Synapse and Cortex. Automatic game detection and overlay. Looking-for-group (LFG) features. Discontinued around 2016.

feature_notes.voice_chat: Integrated overlay with automatic game detection

platforms.name: Curse Voice
platforms.description: Gaming voice chat integrated with Curse client for game mods/addons (2014-2018). Evolved into Discord partnership. Discontinued 2018 after Twitch acquisition.
platforms.notes: Developed by Curse Inc (acquired by Twitch/Amazon 2016). Integrated with Curse client for World of Warcraft addons. Auto-detected teammates in games. Evolved into Twitch app, then deprecated when Twitch partnered with Discord.

feature_notes.voice_chat: Automatic teammate detection in supported games
feature_notes.community_discovery: Integrated with Curse client for World of Warcraft addon management

platforms.name: TeaSpeak
platforms.description: Open-source TeamSpeak 3 server and client reimplementation (2017-2020). Aimed for protocol compatibility with TS3. Discontinued circa 2020.
platforms.notes: Open-source reverse-engineered implementation of TeamSpeak 3 protocol. GPLv3 licensed. Development appears to have ceased around 2020. Project exists as historical reference for open TS3 protocol work.

feature_notes.open_source: GPLv3. Reverse-engineered TeamSpeak 3 protocol for compatibility
feature_notes.web_app: TeaSpeak included a web client interface

platforms.name: Discourse
platforms.description: ⚠️ FORUM SOFTWARE, NOT CHAT: Modern forum platform. Some try to use as Discord replacement - this is a category error. Best for async, long-form discussion.
platforms.notes:
⚠️ CATEGORY ERROR: Discourse is modern FORUM software. Really good forum software. It is NOT chat and NOT a Discord replacement despite some attempting to use it that way.

CHAT PLUGIN: Bundled chat plugin provides short-form, real-time-ish messaging. But Discourse is still async and forum-based at heart. You post, you wait, people reply. NOT instant messaging. If community expects real-time chat, will feel slow and clunky. If community wants thoughtful long-form discussion, Discourse is perfect.

TRUST LEVEL SYSTEM: Gamifies moderation. Transparent mod actions. Best anti-spam tools in business. Reddit-style discussion without Reddit.

BOT SITUATION: Discobot (built-in onboarding bot) is genuinely well done. Beyond that: custom bots via REST API. No plug-and-play marketplace. Growing ecosystem of AI chatbot plugins.

BRIDGING: ONE-WAY ONLY. Chat Integration Plugin sends notifications OUT to Slack, Discord, Telegram, Matrix, Teams, etc. NOT bidirectional chat bridging. Experimental discourse-chat-matrix plugin exists but not production-ready. NOT supported by Matterbridge (Discourse isn't a chat protocol, doesn't fit bridging model).

SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: 2GB RAM minimum, 4GB recommended. Docker-based deployment (heavily pushed). PostgreSQL and Redis. CDN highly recommended for media. Frequent updates.

Real-world assessment (mvh, Feb 2026): "Choose Discourse if you want a FORUM, not chat. Long-form discussion is your goal. Powerful moderation and trust systems needed. You're okay with async communication. Skip if you need real-time chat or bidirectional bridging."

Use case: When your community actually wants Reddit-style forum discussion, not Discord-style instant messaging. Don't try to force it into being something it's not.

feature_notes.text_channels: Categories and topics structure (forum-style, not real-time channels)
feature_notes.threads_forums: Core feature - entire platform is threaded discussions
feature_notes.large_community_moderation: Trust levels, flags, automatic hiding, user silencing, sophisticated moderation
feature_notes.bridges: ONE-WAY notifications out only. NOT bidirectional chat bridging. NOT supported by Matterbridge.
feature_notes.docs_wiki_channels: Wiki-style knowledge base features, long-form documentation support
feature_notes.migration_assistant: Import tools from other forum software (phpBB, vBulletin, etc)
feature_notes.automod: Automatic post hiding based on flags, spam detection, new user restrictions
feature_notes.message_reporting: Flag system - users can flag posts for moderator review
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No built-in AI features. Self-hosted forum software.
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Google Sheet community assessment: NOT vibe-safe. May contain AI-generated code.

platforms.name: Mattermost
platforms.description: Open-source Slack alternative for teams. Self-hosted, E2EE voice/video (Beta), extensive integrations, mobile apps.
platforms.notes: Designed for DevOps/technical teams. Strong focus on security (used by US Department of Defense). Slack-compatible webhooks. Free self-hosted version + paid Enterprise edition. Go backend, React frontend. Excellent mobile apps. Playbooks for incident response, runbooks.

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: E2EE voice/video in beta. Messages encrypted in transit and at rest but not E2EE by default
feature_notes.no_premium_tier: Free self-hosted version available, Enterprise adds compliance/auth features
feature_notes.list_task_channels: Playbooks for runbooks and incident response
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: AI plugin framework available, Microsoft Copilot integration planned

platforms.name: Ventrilo
platforms.description: Legacy gaming voice chat (1997-present). Low-latency, high-quality audio. Surround sound positioning. Widely used in MMO guilds pre-Discord.
platforms.notes: Released 1997 - one of the earliest gaming VoIP solutions. Dominated MMO gaming (WoW, EverQuest) in 2000s-2010s. Server rental model. Known for superior voice quality and low latency. Codec licensing caused pricing model. Lost market share to Discord/TeamSpeak. Still actively developed (last update 2024). Desktop only.

feature_notes.free_to_use: Free client, servers require licensing (rental or self-host with license). Free 8-slot server available.
feature_notes.self_hosting_license: Can self-host but requires commercial license. Free tier limited to 8 slots.
feature_notes.freemium_limitations: Free tier: 8 slots max. Paid: up to 400 slots per server.
feature_notes.voice_chat: High-quality Speex codec with surround sound positioning. Known for superior audio quality.
feature_notes.per_user_audio_output: Individual volume control and audio settings per user
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: No AI features, voice-focused legacy platform

platforms.name: Slack
platforms.description: Popular workplace messaging platform. Channels, threads, integrations, huddles (voice/video). Freemium model with message history limits.
platforms.notes: Dominant workplace collaboration tool. Acquired by Salesforce (2021) for $27.7B. Strong integration ecosystem (2600+ apps). Free tier limits message history to 90 days and 10 integrations. Known for excellent UX but high costs at scale. Desktop/mobile apps are Electron-based.

feature_notes.freemium_limitations: Free: 90-day message history, 10 integrations, 1:1 huddles only. Paid: unlimited history, unlimited integrations, group huddles.
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Encryption in transit and at rest, but Slack has access to messages (not E2EE)
feature_notes.voice_chat: Called 'Huddles' - lightweight voice/video calls in channels
feature_notes.persistent_voice_channels: Huddles are call-based (started/stopped), not persistent channels
feature_notes.threads_forums: Threaded conversations supported, not traditional forums
feature_notes.list_task_channels: Lists feature for simple task tracking, integrates with external tools
feature_notes.docs_wiki_channels: Canvas feature for collaborative docs, not full wiki
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: Slack AI: search, summaries, thread recaps, workflow suggestions. Trains on workspace data.

platforms.name: Microsoft Teams
platforms.description: Microsoft's workplace collaboration platform. Integrated with Office 365. Channels, meetings, file collaboration, extensive Microsoft ecosystem integration.
platforms.notes: Part of Microsoft 365 suite. Deep integration with Office apps (Word, Excel, SharePoint, OneDrive). Used by 320M+ people (2023). Free tier available. Dominant in enterprise due to existing Microsoft contracts. Native Teams app (2023) replaced Electron version for better performance.

feature_notes.federated: Can communicate with external organizations via Teams Connect and Teams federation
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: E2EE for 1:1 calls only (as of 2021). Group calls encrypted in transit.
feature_notes.freemium_limitations: Free: 60-minute meeting limit, 100 participants, 5GB storage per user. Paid: 30-hour meetings, 300+ participants, 1TB+ storage.
feature_notes.voice_chat: Supports meetings (scheduled) and calls (ad-hoc). Meeting features depend on license tier.
feature_notes.persistent_voice_channels: No persistent voice channels - all audio is meeting/call based
feature_notes.list_task_channels: Deep integration with Microsoft Planner and To Do for task management
feature_notes.docs_wiki_channels: Wiki tab available, plus full SharePoint integration for knowledge bases
feature_notes.rich_calendar_tools: Full Outlook calendar integration with meeting scheduling, recurring events, room booking
feature_notes.migration_assistant: Import from Slack available for Enterprise customers
feature_notes.ai_features_or_training: Copilot integration: meeting notes, chat summaries, action items. Trains on Microsoft 365 data.

platforms.name: Amazon Chime
platforms.description: AWS business communications service. Voice/video meetings, chat, screen sharing. Pay-per-use or Pro tier. SDK available for embedding.
platforms.notes: Amazon's answer to Zoom/Teams. Two products: Chime (standalone meetings app, being deprecated) and Chime SDK (programmable real-time comms for developers). AWS is migrating users to Amazon Connect for contact center, and WorkSpaces for desktop collaboration. Chime SDK still actively developed for embedding comms into apps.

feature_notes.free_to_use: Basic (free) supports meetings up to 100 attendees for 30 days trial. Pro tier is pay-per-use.
feature_notes.freemium_limitations: Basic: 30-day trial, limited features. Pro: $15/user/day (only charged on days used), unlimited meetings.
feature_notes.no_data_tracking: AWS standard practices - some metadata collected for service improvement
feature_notes.voice_chat: High-quality audio with background noise suppression
feature_notes.bots_automation: Chime SDK supports building bots with AWS Lambda integration
feature_notes.bridges: Can integrate with calendar systems and other AWS services
feature_notes.rich_calendar_tools: Outlook and Google Calendar integration for meeting scheduling

platforms.name: Paracord
platforms.description: AI-generated Discord alternative with critical security vulnerabilities. NOT recommended for use. Serves as cautionary example of 'vibe-coded' platforms.
platforms.notes: SECURITY WARNING: Community security audit (Feb 2025) found critical vulnerabilities: unauthenticated LiveKit proxy, remote code execution, plaintext secrets, bypassed rate limiting, CORS allows any origin. Developer created using AI in 'a few evenings'. Posted as 'privacy-focused' alternative but has worse security than Discord. NOT SUITABLE FOR PRODUCTION USE. Example of risks with AI-generated security-critical code.

feature_notes.open_source: GitHub repository available but developed privately then dumped as single commit - no development history
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Confirmed AI-generated. Community security audit found 20+ vulnerabilities including RCE, unauthenticated endpoints, plaintext secrets. Developer admits 'built in a few evenings' with AI.
feature_notes.voice_chat: Uses LiveKit but proxy has NO authentication - anyone can join calls silently
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: No E2EE. JWT secrets stored in plaintext in config file.
feature_notes.self_hostable: UPnP auto-opens router ports by default, exposing server to internet without user awareness

platforms.name: Voltage (VoltChat)
platforms.description: Federated, open chat platform. Very new project with limited public information and strong indicators of AI-generated codebase.
platforms.notes: SECURITY WARNING: Extremely new project (10 commits, Feb 2026). Comprehensive backend with federation, OAuth, CDN in minimal commits suggests AI generation. No user base, no security audit, minimal documentation beyond README. Website returns 403 errors. Multiple related repos (Voltage, VoltApp, self-volt, Wire) created simultaneously by Enclicainteractive. Lacks development history typical of human-written projects. Approach with extreme caution.

feature_notes.open_source: GitHub repos available but extremely new (Feb 2026)
feature_notes.federated: Claims federation support ('Self-Volt') but unproven with no federated instances
feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Listed in feature flags but implementation status unknown
feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Strong indicators: 10 commits with full-featured backend, comprehensive docs, federation/OAuth/CDN all at once, no development history, multiple simultaneous repos. Typical vibe-coding pattern.
feature_notes.self_hostable: Setup scripts provided but untested by community
feature_notes.community_discovery: Listed in feature flags but no public instance to verify

platforms.name: Critterchat
platforms.description: Self-hosted web chat providing Discord-like channels, group chat, and DMs. Focus on ease of use over encryption. Federation support planned.
platforms.notes: Small project (8 stars) with active development (482 commits). Explicitly states: 'Not built with, enabled by or integrated with any generative AI.' No encryption focus - prioritizes simplicity. Open registration with admin approval.

feature_notes.ai_generated_codebase: Explicitly states: 'Not built with, enabled by or integrated with any generative AI.'
feature_notes.federated: Federation between instances planned but not yet implemented (FEDERATION.md exists)
feature_notes.file_sharing: Image attachments currently supported, arbitrary file attachments on wishlist

platforms.name: Polyproto
platforms.description: ⚠️ NOT END-USER SOFTWARE: Federated identity and message exchange protocol for developers building chat/social apps. Similar to Matrix Protocol or ActivityPub. No standalone chat app exists.
platforms.notes: PROTOCOL, NOT APPLICATION: This is infrastructure for building federated apps, not something end users can download. Uses X.509 certificates, digital signatures, 'boring technology' approach. Reference implementation (Symfonia) is archived. For developers, not end users.

feature_notes.self_hostable: N/A - This is a protocol specification, not software. Implementations would be self-hostable.
feature_notes.hardware_required_for_use: N/A - No end-user application exists. Protocol for developers to build upon.

platforms.name: Carrion
platforms.description: ⚠️ ADULT CONTENT (18+): Privacy-focused adult roleplay platform with zero server-side message storage. Designed for erotic RP, kink communities, LGBTQ+, and furries. NOT a general chat alternative.
platforms.notes: ADULT PLATFORM: Built specifically for erotic roleplay and adult communities. Messages relay through server RAM (~50ms) with no disk storage. Iceland-based hosting. Solo developer project. NOT comparable to Discord - serves entirely different purpose. Quote: 'not a discord replacement unless you only use discord for typefucking.'

feature_notes.e2e_encryption: Encrypted DMs available. Messages pass through server RAM briefly but not stored on disk.
feature_notes.message_ttl: Messages only exist in browser IndexedDB. Can export/import, but server stores nothing.

platforms.name: Apoka
platforms.description: Closed-source centralized chat platform with privacy focus.
platforms.notes: Limited public information available. Closed source. No self-hosting option. Centralized hosting model.

platforms.name: Session
platforms.description: End-to-end encrypted messenger built on onion-routed privacy network. More like Signal than Discord - not designed for large community servers.
platforms.notes:
Privacy-maximalist messenger with strong anonymity focus via onion routing network. No phone number required to create account. 

NOT DESIGNED FOR DISCORD-LIKE COMMUNITIES: Session is a private messenger (1-to-1 or small groups), not a platform for large persistent community servers. Performance varies due to underlying privacy network.

From discordless.com: "End-to-end encrypted messenger built on a privacy-preserving network; feels more like Signal than Discord. Not designed for large, Discord-like community servers."

Australia-based. Strong privacy focus, but OS telemetry, backups, or device malware can still compromise security.

platforms.name: RetroShare
platforms.description: Open source, decentralized P2P platform for encrypted chat, voice/video calls, anonymous file sharing with swarming, censorship-resistant forums, and offline messaging.
platforms.notes:
Peer-to-peer encrypted communication platform with strong privacy focus. Uses OpenPGP and OpenSSL for security.

Features include: encrypted chat, secure voice/video calls, anonymous file sharing with BitTorrent-style swarming, forums, channels, link sharing, and offline messaging.

From AlternativeTo: 163 likes, described as "decentralized platform enabling encrypted chat, secure voice and video calls, anonymous file sharing with swarming, censorship-resistant forums."

P2P requires direct connectivity; NAT/firewalls may require configuration. Not designed for large Discord-style servers - more focused on small trusted groups with strong privacy needs.

platforms.name: Strafe
platforms.description: Open source encrypted chat platform with E2EE messaging, markdown support, file sharing, self-hosting, voice/video calls, and no data tracking.
platforms.notes:
Privacy-focused open source chat server for small to medium communities. Emphasizes end-to-end encryption and transparent codebase.

Features: E2EE messaging, uncensored communication, markdown support, file sharing, self-hosting capability, multi-device sync, server management tools, voice and video calls.

From AlternativeTo: 7 likes, described as "open source chat platform offering end-to-end encrypted messaging, uncensored communication, markdown support, file sharing, self-hosting."

Community-driven development with transparent codebase on GitHub. Self-hostable with full control over data and configuration.

platforms.name: Common Ground
platforms.description: Browser-based, open-source social platform for communities built as a robust alternative to Discord.
platforms.notes:
Web-based open source community platform explicitly designed as Discord alternative.

Features: Custom functionalities, global activity feed, voice/video calls, instant messaging, browser-based access (no downloads required).

From AlternativeTo: 4 likes, described as "browser-based, open-source social platform for communities, built as a robust alternative to Discord."

Screenshot shows ability to play games (VoxeLibre) directly in browser alongside chat. Focus on browser accessibility and custom functionality for communities.

Early stage project - expect evolving features and documentation.

platforms.name: Conduit
platforms.description: Lightweight Matrix homeserver written in Rust - simple, fast, and reliable alternative to Synapse for self-hosting.
platforms.notes:
Lightweight Matrix homeserver designed as alternative to Synapse. Focus: simplicity, speed, low resource usage.

IMPORTANT: This is SERVER SOFTWARE (like Synapse), not an end-user client. Users connect via Matrix clients (Element, Cinny, etc.).

Advantages over Synapse:
- Much lighter resource requirements (runs on Raspberry Pi)
- Easier installation and maintenance
- Written in Rust for performance and safety
- Faster startup times
- Lower memory footprint

From AlternativeTo: 6 likes, described as "simple, fast and reliable chat server powered by Matrix. Conduit is an alternative to Synapse and tries to be lightweight and easy to install."

Still in development - may have incomplete features compared to mature Synapse. Best for self-hosters who find Synapse too resource-heavy.

Supports: Raspberry Pi, Linux, Debian, Docker, Nix Package Manager.

feature_notes.self_hostable: Lightweight Matrix homeserver - much easier to run than Synapse, works on Raspberry Pi

platforms.name: 0xchat
platforms.description: Secure chat app built on Nostr protocol with private key login, encrypted private chats and contacts, encrypted group chats.
platforms.notes:
Privacy-focused chat built on decentralized Nostr protocol. Uses cryptographic keys instead of traditional accounts.

Features: Private key login (no email/phone required), encrypted private chats, encrypted contacts, encrypted group chats, decentralized architecture (no central servers).

From AlternativeTo: 4 likes, described as "secure chat app built on the Nostr protocol. It prioritizes security, featuring private key login, encrypted private chats and contacts, encrypted group chats."

Nostr protocol advantages:
- Censorship resistant (no central authority)
- User owns identity via cryptographic keys
- Can switch between different Nostr apps with same identity
- No phone number or email required

Cross-platform: Android, iPhone, Windows, Linux, macOS, BSD.

Similar to Flotilla (also Nostr-based) but focused on private messaging rather than communities.
